newsitem.title: BELARUS: Belarus head says deal impossible with parliament.
newsitem.headline: Belarus head says deal impossible with parliament.

text.p: Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko stormed out of parliament on Friday and said he would "go directly to the people" after failing to win support for a referendum that could boost his political powers.
Lukashenko, accused by opponents of an authoritarian style of government, withdrew proposals intended to reach a compromise with parliament in a dispute over a planned referundum on the constitution.
"I do not see any opportunity to find a compromise in this parliament. I will go directly to the people and I will withdraw my initiative, and the people will be our judge," Lukashenko said.
Lukashenko made his compromise proposal on Thursday but was angered after his plans were criticised by the head of the constitutional court.
The referendum scheduled for November 7 would grant Lukashenko a 10-year mandate and has been sharply criticised by parliamentarians in the former Soviet republic.

Lukashenko had held out an olive branch by offering deputies wider powers if they shelved plans for a separate referendum on their own proposed constitution planned for November 24, but he had vowed to press on with his own referendum.
